awd_titl_txt: CIVIC-PG Track B: Community Food Mobilization in Chicago
awd_abstract_narration:
The Chicagoland Food Research-Centered Pilot Project (ChiFood-RCPP) addresses a pressing research need identified by communities of Black, Indigenous and People of Color (BIPOC) food practitioners: how to restructure the food production, distribution and consumption system to center their aspirations of creating equitable access to nourishing and culturally-affirming foods, while self-determining the scale and scope of their work in the food system. The pilot project uses the Good Food Purchasing Initiative (GFPI), a policy platform adopted in both the City of Chicago and Cook County, as a vehicle for local public institutions, BIPOC producers and workers to chart pathways to achieve these goals. The team will conduct research in social, geographic and data sciences along with design and management, to investigate processes for innovating public procurement processes, while incorporating diverse values, and social, economic and environmental objectives. ChiFood-RCPP advances multi-disciplinary research to build access to essential resources and services that meet community needs. The pilot will uncover and test pathways to operationalize equity goals through food policy work, in partnership with key stakeholders. Coalitions of researchers and practitioners throughout the U.S. can replicate these pilot approaches with diverse participants across the food value chain. 

For decades, Black, Indigenous and People of Color (BIPOC) activists have leveled critiques that the values, culture and infrastructures shaping food markets and policies perpetuate racial disparities in food producers’ and consumers’ access to food, foodways, economic benefits and health outcomes. Vertically-integrated food businesses dominate the food supply chain, operating with knowledge and capital to play on massive economies of scale, which limit the ability of small and BIPOC-owned businesses to compete on level playing fields. This project addresses asymmetries in the food system by exploring and developing data and models centered on the goals of BIPOC food practitioners, meal recipients and advocates. It places these resources in their and procurement officials' hands to ensure research findings are relevant, actionable and self-sustainable. Researchers will explore 1) mechanisms for incorporating diverse stakeholders’ values, meanings and visions into food systems transformation; 2) data and models that advance equitable local food supply chain development; 3) prototypes of network, policy and participatory structures to engage BIPOC food communities (producers, workers, entrepreneurs, eaters) in culturally-affirming, scale-appropriate strategies; and 4) a roadmap of frameworks and pathways to systemize an inclusive food system culture that honors a plurality of values and practices, offers market channel flexibility and guides community food mobilization goals. This project is in response to the Civic Innovation Challenge program—Track B. Bridging the gap between essential resources and services & community needs—and is a collaboration between NSF, the Department of Homeland Security, and the Department of Energy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Community Food MOBilization in Chicago (CF-MOB) Pilot Project will investigate how to transform food production and distribution in ways that center racial justice, sovereignty and community food access. It aims to advance understanding of public procurement's role in investing in local, equitable food supply chain development, while empowering and creating space for Black, Indigenous and People of Color (BIPOC) food stakeholders to self-determine their participation in it. CF-MOB is built on strong existing multi-sectoral partnerships among food producers, workers, eaters, advocates, government agency representatives and researchers around the Metro Chicago Good Food Purchasing Initiative (GFPI). 

As envisioned in the planning grant, the project addressed a pressing research need identified by the Chicagoland community of food practitioners to investigate the constellation of levers and pathways for rearticulating the structures of food production and distribution in  ways that center racial justice, sovereignty and community food mobilization. This vision went beyond market-oriented solutions and encompasses the full spectrum of participation and community efforts to prioritize and secure equitable access to nourishing food, nutrition, wellness and cultural systems in impacted communities. We employed social science, geographic, business and design research to investigate explicit and implicit processes that activate, or inhibit, levers for bringing the above vision into reality. This planning grant and proposed pilot project builds on the work of the Metro Chicago Good Food Purchasing Initiative (GFPI), which uses community food access sites as vehicles for food system transformation, to invest in local, BIPOC-led, humane, sustainable and just food cultivation, aggregation, processing and distribution operations.

The CIVIC Stage 1 planning grant enabled the team to pursue three major goals: (1) convene stakeholders (food producers, workers, buyers and eaters) to understand their diverse visions for a racially equitable, sustainable, and resilient food system; (2) identify and prioritize questions around product discovery and procurement pathways with public agencies and food service providers; and (3) plan outreach with broader food practitioner and eater communities to collaboratively design pilot and research activities

The CF-MOB team convened over 100 stakeholders via 1:1 interviews, two bi-monthly GFPI leadership meetings, five focus groups, and two in-person public forums hosted by the Chicago Food Policy Action Council - the Good Food & Urban Ag Forum in December 2022 and Chicago Food Justice Summit in February 2023. There were over 150 attendees at each forum, including small farmers (with strong representation by farmers of color), institutional representatives, food supply chain representatives, students and the general public.  At both forums, the CF-MOB research team hosted an expo booth where attendees could obtain information about the project and GFPI, as well as share their experiences and perspectives regarding institutional "good food" procurement, and challenges they face in participating in institutional supply chains. In addition, the team hosted design-led workshops during breakout sessions at both forums, with 30+ participants directly engaged in each. The team used two in-person, half-day focus groups in January 2023, one focused on BIPOC suppliers and one focused on institutional buyers, each with ~25 participants, to take deep dives into the research questions and refine plans for the pilot project. A key task during the planning grant was to identify institutions with whom we would work to identify and model procurement workflows and budgets for specific products.  The Chicago Public Schools (CPS) system, Chicago Department of Family & Social Services (DFSS) and the Cook County Juvenile Temporary Detention Center (JTDC) were selected as pilot institutions, each with distinct challenges to address, and which will serve as models for future work

The team used these opportunities for dialogue to solidify the pilot project?s research plan focusing on structural barriers and practitioner experiences along the food supply chain, including the community's diverse visions to design a set of innovative, food mobilization pathways. Research priorities identified for the Stage 2 pilot project are to (1) categorize and visualize food system stakeholders' pluralistic visions for providing and receiving culturally-affirming meals through institutional and other community food access programs; (2) identify a short list of GFPP-aligned and locally-, BIPOC-produced priority products for the three public institutions (CPS, DFSS and JTDC); (3) evaluate and demonstrate their economic, sustainable and cultural value to competitively position these products vis a vis dominant supply channels; (4) identify policies and practices inhibiting shifts to values-based purchasing in institutional procurement food supply chains; and (5) prototype the Metro Chicago Good Food Dashboard, a web-based interface increasing public access to current institutional purchasing data and connecting BIPOC growers and workers to GFPP-aligned procurement opportunities with City and County institutions.
